DAVID SOLOMON, CO-PRESIDENT, GOLDMAN SACHS, IS INTERVIEWED ON BLOOMBERG TV

MAY 1, 2017

SPEAKERS: DAVID SOLOMON, CO-PRESIDENT, GOLDMAN SACHS

ERIK SCHATZKER, BLOOMBERG NEWS

[*] SCHATZKER: I'm here with David Solomon. He's the co-president of Goldman Sachs. David, good morning.

SOLOMON: Good morning, Erik. Nice to be here with you.

SCHATZKER: Nice to see you again. We'll begin with the obvious. I think the general consensus is that Goldman had by Goldman standards a rough first quarter. It's a trading business back on track.

SOLOMON: Our trading business is a great franchise. We work very, very hard, you know, to serve our clients. Clearly, we didn't meet expectations in the first quarter. You know, although, when you look at the firm broadly, IBD, or Investment Management division, the equities divisions, all performed in line. The FICC, you know, FICC did not. So look, it's great opportunity to take a look at the margin and see what's going on in the business and other ways that we can continue to invest, tighten up the franchise, understand why in the quarter that we were presented with, we got a slightly different result, but we feel very good about our client franchise and our position in the business.

SCHATZKER: So now that you have had an opportunity to take a close look, what conclusions have you drawn?

SOLOMON: You know, the conclusions are that we drew in looking at the quarter, where there a number of things about the quarter that just given our mix of clients and the way we're positioned and the way we navigate at the quarter, it didn't lead to the best performance for us. But look, we could look back the last quarter, we outperformed by an equal amount. And, you know, we've got a business where we're working with clients, we work with them, their activity levels, the flows that they have. We're in certain businesses that some of our competitors are not in like the commodities business, et cetera.

And based on that mix of businesses, we can have a slightly different result than others. But we've got a really terrific franchise. I obviously can't comment on other peoples', you know, earnings. But when I look at our relative and competitive position, I feel great about our people, the work we're doing for our clients and the way those businesses are positioned.

SCHATZKER: Are those positions still losing money?

SOLOMON: There -- there are positions that are losing money. You -- you kind of pop that right in. I assume you're referring to the article, the -- the Bloomberg -- the -- the -- the credit article that Bloomberg wrote. I wouldn't put a lot of credence into that. This was not a quarter that was defined by positions losing money. This was a quarter that was defined by lower client activity. And the firm, not maximizing the revenue opportunity. But look, we had a few hundred million dollars more money, more revenue on those businesses, we probably wouldn't be having this discussion.

SCHATZKER: So strictly a matter of planned activity and nothing to do with, say, a risk management problem?

SOLOMON: No, there's absolutely no risk management problem. That was not what defined that the quarter at all. This was a quarter that was defined by low volatility, a lack of conviction with our clients, and one of the things that I'd say is our business is definitely weighted or levered to times when our clients have a lot of conviction. I think one of the things that happened in the first quarter is conviction kind of ebbed and flowed away a little after period in the fourth quarter after the election when people were very, very conflicted about the reflation trade, and that backed off a little bit during the quarter.

SCHATZKER: You know why we're talking about this. We're talking about it for two principal reasons. One is Goldman has a record, a track record of consistently beating earnings expectations, and secondly, of course, all of your competitors had double-digit increases in FICC trade ...

(AUDIO GAP)

SOLOMON: Erik, we didn't meet expectations this quarter. OK? It's not the first quarter we didn't.

(CROSSTALK)

SCHATZKER: It doesn't happen very often.

SOLOMON: But it happened this quarter. We've got a terrific franchise. We feel very good about our franchise. There's no risk management issue. We feel -- we feel very, very good about the work we're doing for our clients in the way we're positioned.

(CROSSTALK)

SOLOMON: ... we didn't meet expectations this quarter.

SCHATZKER: We know. Do you do anything differently going forward?

SOLOMON: You know, I think when you had a situation where you don't meet expectations, you take a hard look at your business. And, you know, our people are always very, very intense around our clients, what their clients' needs are and the activity of the services we provide, and you just redouble out all that, make sure that you're doing -- if you spend time talking to your clients, covering your clients, delivering value for your clients over a long period of time, good things happen. And we feel very good about the way we're positioned.

SCHATZKER: FICC is getting all the attention. But equities wasn't the star performer it's been in the past either. Five years ago, Goldman's equities business was twice as large as Morgan Stanley's and now Morgan Stanley's is bigger. What happened?

SOLOMON: Yeah. Well, Morgan Stanley -- Morgan Stanley, definitely, the businesses are weighted in different ways. We have a leading institutional equity franchise. We've got a strong position across institutional work, high touch, low touch, also prime brokerage. But one of the places where we're not as invested as Morgan Stanley is in -- is in quants. And there are variety of reasons. It's a business that's grown very significantly and Morgan Stanley has a bigger position in that business. And that ...

SCHATZKER: What do you do about it?

SOLOMON: Well, it's actually -- it's a business we're investing in. But candidly, it's a business, it's not a straightforward business. There's lots of operational risks in that business. And while we're investing in it, we want to be in that business. You know, we -- we're -- we've been a little bit more cautious in terms of our investment in that business, but we're building up that capability. And Morgan Stanley has a platform of quants that's a little bit larger. But if you look at the institutional business away from that, you know, we have a very, very significant institutional leading equity franchise.

SCHATZKER: Can you take some of that market share and quant away from Morgan Stanley?

SOLOMON: I think there are opportunities with a set of clients that we don't do as much business with to increase our market share with those clients. We're focused on that.

SCHATZKER: How?

SOLOMON: By continuing to invest in technology and making sure our offering, which has developed meaningfully over the course over the last year, (inaudible) continuous to develop and is competitive. Now, we started to grow our market share with some of those clients and that's something we're going to continue to focus on.

SCHATZKER: At what point did it become clear that, if you will, a strategic error had been made and not investing in quant early enough?

SOLOMON: Well, I wouldn't say that it was a strategic error. I would say it was a choice that was made. You know, you only see over time how all these businesses run. And look, part of this -- we're not always just looking for revenue in these businesses. We're also looking for returns. OK? And it's -- it's a -- it's a balance. And so, you know, I know that you want to point to it and say, this is a strategic error. You know, we've run our business. We have a leading equity franchise. We're very focused on returns, which is one of the reasons why when you look at our returns as an institution, we've outperformed the competitive peer (ph) set over a long period of time.

We're focused on returns. We're focused on servicing our clients. And, you know, at times, people pick and choose to be in different investments. But over time, you know, you balance that out, you hopefully make the right long-term decisions.

SCHATZKER: Now that you're co-president of the firm, many people may forget that once upon a time, you're a leveraged finance guy.

SOLOMON: That was -- that was a once upon a time. I still watch that market very closely.

SCHATZKER: I'm sure you do. There is a lot of that capital available for M&A right now, and financing terms appear to be getting very loose, would you agree?

SOLOMON: You know, look, when you look at the leveraged finance market at the moment, we're definitely running at relatively tight, you know, robust levels. You know, I think when I look just over the weekend, we're running kind of a two-year tight, and there's obviously been a big momentum of funds into the loan market, the floating rate market, obviously, given the interest rate environment we're potentially moving into. But even high-yield activity is up significantly, obviously, off a low base last year but up significantly.

And the pricing, you know, very, very tight. So we're in a relatively robust environment at the moment, but I wouldn't say there's been a lot of supply. And I wouldn't say that leverage levels, given the regulatory environment on a significant amount of the product, have really been pressed that significantly. So ...

SCHATZKER: Is Goldman doing what your shareholders would want, which is to say being prudent about how it uses its balance sheet and leveraged finance?

SOLOMON: Absolutely. We -- we -- we have very, very strong risk management culture. Leveraged finance business, and important business to service our client, but, you know, I'd say from an overall perspective, our leveraged finance risk are deal risk given the activity we've had. We -- we have some on our books but it's lower actually than what I'd like to see at this point in time. There actually hasn't been as much of that activity, that M&A activity, that -- that financing activities we're like to see.

SCHATZKER: So I'm going to do something which you would probably consider unfair, which is pick on a single deal.

SOLOMON: OK.

SCHATZKER: OK. Charter NEX. This is a packaging company that Leonard Green is buying the leveraged buyout, and Goldman is providing the junior financing. $245 million of junior debt all unsecured, all balance sheet lending, 7.1 times leverage, covenant-lite LIBOR plus 775, or with a PIK-toggle LIBOR plus 825.

SOLOMON: So you've now -- you've now -- in -- in about 30 seconds, you've now exceeded my knowledge of this particular transaction by a very, very wide margin. But what I can say is the leadership of the firm feels very, very good about our risk management processes around this product. We have a leading franchise in the leveraged finance business, but part of the leveraged finance business is it's a risk management business, you have to have a strong risk management culture. And I'm sure we have a team that's looking carefully at this transaction, has a strong point of view about the distribution capability of the transaction. And, you know, we're very disciplined in the way we underwrite.

SCHATZKER: In general terms, PIK toggle and cov lite sound a lot like 2007.

SOLOMON: You know, in general terms, those were -- those were tools that were used, you know, first in that time period, 2005 through 2007. Like anything else, you know, it's a question of balance. None of these things are black-and-white, good or bad, it's the extent to how they're used, on what kind of leverage in the capital structure to what -- to what degree, and how much instrumental or fundamental leverage they're creating in a transaction. So I'm not familiar with these transactions, so I can't comment on the specific transaction.

But I'd say, generally speaking, the leveraged finance market is getting robust, but defaults are low, the economic environment is quite constructive, and it's something to watch. It's always a space to watch. But I would say while it's tighter and a little bit more aggressive, I don't think we're at the point where we're right at the end of that running. A lot of it is going to be correlated to the economic environment here. And to some degree, deal activity, you know, has not really expanded in a way that's really built up a much, much larger calendar ...

SCHATZKER: You raised an important point. Do you believe sitting here right now that the valuations we see in the equity market and the credit market reflect a realistic expectation for economic activity?

SOLOMON: You know, look, it's hard -- it's hard to answer a question like that. I know that the people would point to the fact and say that if you look at the S&P valuation, it's a top decile valuation when you look historically. However, in 1995, it was a top decile valuation that we ran for another five years before we saw a significant hiccup in the market. A lot of it's based on, you know, where the earnings momentum goes from here. And I think corporate earnings actually are pretty good. If you look at earnings so far this quarter, you know, we're really operating in a pretty strong corporate earnings environment.

SCHATZKER: And analysts are raising estimates.

SOLOMON: And analysts are raising estimates. Now, we've only seen kind of half the picture. We've seen a lot of industrials, financials, big tech, there's still more to go with respect to consumer, REITs (ph), energy, but you've got a pretty good earnings environment, you've got a lot of economic policy that's been talked about, which could be good for asset prices in markets. You know, I think, for the moment, that's got people kind of hanging in. And, you know, we'll have to watch and see. Do we get some momentum on the policy side? Can we get tax reform in some way? All that could be constructive.

So I'd say, you've got to watch very carefully, but there's no question valuations are (inaudible) in the equity markets at the moment. If you don't maintain this earnings momentum and the growth that we have in the economy, we get the 3 percent growth, you know, I don't think you and I will be saying that these market multiples, you know, look high when we look back at that point, but we have to watch and see.

SCHATZKER: Well, the one thing that doesn't make sense, or that I'm having trouble calculating, those valuations in the equity market, the tightness of credit spreads, but the 10-year, 228.

SOLOMON: You know, it's -- there's -- there's a lot going on, and there's a lot of uncertainty and it's a complicated -- it's a complicated matrix. But generally speaking, you would have expected, you know, more movement in that. But generally, we've all had that, you know, that's -- that's -- that's not the way things have played out over the course of the last few months.

SCHATZKER: David, so good to see you.

SOLOMON: Always good to see you.

SCHATZKER: Thanks for your time.

SOLOMON: Thanks for your time. (Inaudible).

SCHATZKER: Oliver, that's David Solomon. He's the co-president of Goldman Sachs, here at the Milken Global Conference in Beverly Hills.

***END OF TRANSCRIPT***

And we feel very good about the way we're positioned.

SCHATZKER: FICC is getting all the attention. But equities wasn't the star performer it's been in the past either. Five years ago, Goldman's equities business was twice as large as Morgan Stanley's and now Morgan Stanley's is bigger. What happened?

SOLOMON: Yeah. Well, Morgan Stanley -- Morgan Stanley, definitely, the businesses are weighted in different ways. We have a leading institutional equity franchise. We've got a strong position across institutional work, high touch, low touch, also prime brokerage. But one of the places where we're not as invested as Morgan Stanley is in -- is in quants. And there are variety of reasons. It's a business that's grown very significantly and Morgan Stanley has a bigger position in that business. And that ...

SCHATZKER: What do you do about it?

SOLOMON: Well, it's actually -- it's a business we're investing in. But candidly, it's a business, it's not a straightforward business. There's lots of operational risks in that business. And while we're investing in it, we want to be in that business. You know, we -- we're -- we've been a little bit more cautious in terms of our investment in that business, but we're building up that capability. And Morgan Stanley has a platform of quants that's a little bit larger. But if you look at the institutional business away from that, you know, we have a very, very significant institutional leading equity franchise.

SCHATZKER: Can you take some of that market share and quant away from Morgan Stanley?

SOLOMON: I think there are opportunities with a set of clients that we don't do as much business with to increase our market share with those clients. We're focused on that.

SCHATZKER: How?

SOLOMON: By continuing to invest in technology and making sure our offering, which has developed meaningfully over the course over the last year, (inaudible) continuous to develop and is competitive. Now, we started to grow our market share with some of those clients and that's something we're going to continue to focus on.

SCHATZKER: At what point did it become clear that, if you will, a strategic error had been made and not investing in quant early enough?

SOLOMON: Well, I wouldn't say that it was a strategic error. I would say it was a choice that was made. You know, you only see over time how all these businesses run. And look, part of this -- we're not always just looking for revenue in these businesses. We're also looking for returns. OK? And it's -- it's a -- it's a balance. And so, you know, I know that you want to point to it and say, this is a strategic error. You know, we've run our business. We have a leading equity franchise. We're very focused on returns, which is one of the reasons why when you look at our returns as an institution, we've outperformed the competitive peer (ph) set over a long period of time.

We're focused on returns. We're focused on servicing our clients. And, you know, at times, people pick and choose to be in different investments. But over time, you know, you balance that out, you hopefully make the right long-term decisions.

SCHATZKER: Now that you're co-president of the firm, many people may forget that once upon a time, you're a leveraged finance guy.

SOLOMON: That was -- that was a once upon a time. I still watch that market very closely.

SCHATZKER: I'm sure you do. There is a lot of that capital available for M&A right now, and financing terms appear to be getting very loose, would you agree?

SOLOMON: You know, look, when you look at the leveraged finance market at the moment, we're definitely running at relatively tight, you know, robust levels. You know, I think when I look just over the weekend, we're running kind of a two-year tight, and there's obviously been a big momentum of funds into the loan market, the floating rate market, obviously, given the interest rate environment we're potentially moving into. But even high-yield activity is up significantly, obviously, off a low base last year but up significantly.

And the pricing, you know, very, very tight. So we're in a relatively robust environment at the moment, but I wouldn't say there's been a lot of supply. And I wouldn't say that leverage levels, given the regulatory environment on a significant amount of the product, have really been pressed that significantly. So ...

SCHATZKER: Is Goldman doing what your shareholders would want, which is to say being prudent about how it uses its balance sheet and leveraged finance?

SOLOMON: Absolutely. We -- we -- we have very, very strong risk management culture. Leveraged finance business, and important business to service our client, but, you know, I'd say from an overall perspective, our leveraged finance risk are deal risk given the activity we've had. We -- we have some on our books but it's lower actually than what I'd like to see at this point in time. There actually hasn't been as much of that activity, that M&A activity, that -- that financing activities we're like to see.

SCHATZKER: So I'm going to do something which you would probably consider unfair, which is pick on a single deal.

SOLOMON: OK.

SCHATZKER: OK. Charter NEX. This is a packaging company that Leonard Green is buying the leveraged buyout, and Goldman is providing the junior financing. $245 million of junior debt all unsecured, all balance sheet lending, 7.1 times leverage, covenant-lite LIBOR plus 775, or with a PIK-toggle LIBOR plus 825.

SOLOMON: So you've now -- you've now -- in -- in about 30 seconds, you've now exceeded my knowledge of this particular transaction by a very, very wide margin. But what I can say is the leadership of the firm feels very, very good about our risk management processes around this product. We have a leading franchise in the leveraged finance business, but part of the leveraged finance business is it's a risk management business, you have to have a strong risk management culture. And I'm sure we have a team that's looking carefully at this transaction, has a strong point of view about the distribution capability of the transaction. And, you know, we're very disciplined in the way we underwrite.

SCHATZKER: In general terms, PIK toggle and cov lite sound a lot like 2007.

SOLOMON: You know, in general terms, those were -- those were tools that were used, you know, first in that time period, 2005 through 2007. Like anything else, you know, it's a question of balance. None of these things are black-and-white, good or bad, it's the extent to how they're used, on what kind of leverage in the capital structure to what -- to what degree, and how much instrumental or fundamental leverage they're creating in a transaction. So I'm not familiar with these transactions, so I can't comment on the specific transaction.

But I'd say, generally speaking, the leveraged finance market is getting robust, but defaults are low, the economic environment is quite constructive, and it's something to watch. It's always a space to watch. But I would say while it's tighter and a little bit more aggressive, I don't think we're at the point where we're right at the end of that running. A lot of it is going to be correlated to the economic environment here. And to some degree, deal activity, you know, has not really expanded in a way that's really built up a much, much larger calendar ...

SCHATZKER: You raised an important point. Do you believe sitting here right now that the valuations we see in the equity market and the credit market reflect a realistic expectation for economic activity?

SOLOMON: You know, look, it's hard -- it's hard to answer a question like that. I know that the people would point to the fact and say that if you look at the S&P valuation, it's a top decile valuation when you look historically. However, in 1995, it was a top decile valuation that we ran for another five years before we saw a significant hiccup in the market. A lot of it's based on, you know, where the earnings momentum goes from here. And I think corporate earnings actually are pretty good. If you look at earnings so far this quarter, you know, we're really operating in a pretty strong corporate earnings environment.

SCHATZKER: And analysts are raising estimates.

SOLOMON: And analysts are raising estimates. Now, we've only seen kind of half the picture. We've seen a lot of industrials, financials, big tech, there's still more to go with respect to consumer, REITs (ph), energy, but you've got a pretty good earnings environment, you've got a lot of economic policy that's been talked about, which could be good for asset prices in markets. You know, I think, for the moment, that's got people kind of hanging in. And, you know, we'll have to watch and see. Do we get some momentum on the policy side? Can we get tax reform in some way? All that could be constructive.

So I'd say, you've got to watch very carefully, but there's no question valuations are (inaudible) in the equity markets at the moment. If you don't maintain this earnings momentum and the growth that we have in the economy, we get the 3 percent growth, you know, I don't think you and I will be saying that these market multiples, you know, look high when we look back at that point, but we have to watch and see.

SCHATZKER: Well, the one thing that doesn't make sense, or that I'm having trouble calculating, those valuations in the equity market, the tightness of credit spreads, but the 10-year, 228.

SOLOMON: You know, it's -- there's -- there's a lot going on, and there's a lot of uncertainty and it's a complicated -- it's a complicated matrix. But generally speaking, you would have expected, you know, more movement in that. But generally, we've all had that, you know, that's -- that's -- that's not the way things have played out over the course of the last few months.

SCHATZKER: David, so good to see you.

SOLOMON: Always good to see you.

SCHATZKER: Thanks for your time.

SOLOMON: Thanks for your time. (Inaudible).

SCHATZKER: Oliver, that's David Solomon. He's the co-president of Goldman Sachs, here at the Milken Global Conference in Beverly Hills.

***END OF TRANSCRIPT***

Discussion regarding mergers and acquisitions

(This is not a legal transcript. Bloomberg LP cannot guarantee its accuracy.)

GREGG LEMKAU, GLOBAL HEAD OF M&A, GOLDMAN SACHS, ON BLOOMBERG TV

JANUARY 9, 2017

SPEAKERS: GREGG LEMKAU, GLOBAL HEAD OF M&A, GOLDMAN SACHS

JEFFREY MCCRACKEN, EXECUTIVE EDITOR FOR GLOBAL WHEEL, BLOOMBERG

[*] MCCRACKEN: Thank you, Bonnie. Yeah, you're right, it's quite a list. Welcome, Gregg.

LEMKAU: Thank you.

MCCRACKEN: So, 2016 was a good year, not quite up to the standards of say 2015. We had obviously big global deals, buyer in Monsanto, A.T., Time Warner, et cetera. What do you looking at 2017? What is your crystal ball say?

LEMKAU: Well, I think the outlook for M&A in 2017 is quite strong. A lot of the factors that existed in 2015 and '16 that drive activity continue to persist. So you have low interest rates. You got abundantly available capital. You've got limited growth opportunities for corporate organically. And you have positive equity markets.

So that's all still in place. I think more importantly, some of the headwinds we saw in 2016, it's slowdown activity, are started this upside. And I think specifically, the regulatory environment. I think the expectation is we'll have a little bit of an easier regulatory ..

(BREAK)

MCCRACKEN: Thanks again, Vonnie. I appreciate it. Sorry about that, Gregg.

LEMKAU: Sure.

MCCRACKEN: And I want to talk, so we wanted to give him an opportunity.

LEMKAU: Good idea.

MCCRACKEN: As you were saying, you expect easier regulatory environment in 2017.

LEMKAU: Yes. I think the expectation 2017 will be a bit of a loose for regulatory environment. And when you combine that with what we expect to be corporate tax reform, and in particular cash repatriation. It's actually a general sense of optimism in the business community, in particular, in corporate America that seems to be driving the desire to go out and be much more proactive on the strategic front.

MCCRACKEN: So how does repatriation? Is that something that's talk a lot about by, a lot by the M&A bankers in the M&A words? How do you think that might impact M&A? Because so many deals we've seen, you know, J&J right now talking to Kellyanne, a lot of these companies with offshore cast have used that to do deals in Europe, what happens if they bring that cash back to United States?

LEMKAU: So there something between $1 trillion to $2 trillion of cash trapped offshore by U.S. companies, and now the expectation will be able to bring that back in a relatively low tax rate and deployed in the U.S., so under deployed in a form of capital expenditures or in the form of M&A.

You've seen companies do lots of acquisitions outside the U.S. using that cash, but there a lot more targets in the U.S. and I think companies with the ability to deploy that capital in the U.S. whether it's a trillion or $2 trillion, and the cash that continue to generate back in the U.S., you'll see a big pick up in activity domestically.

MCCRACKEN: Yeah. And what are the industries that have the most offshore cash, is it tech for the most product?

LEMKAU: It's really the biggest the company. So it's mostly tech in big pharma but it's Google, Apple, Microsoft, Pfizer, J&J. You saw a lot of companies in the pharmaceutical industry, trying to do things to be able to access that cash offshore via M&A. If they can just bring that back and use it and deploy it via M&A in the U.S. they'll be able to do that much more easily.

MCCRACKEN: So they can bring it back, they'll use it for dividens. They'll use it for probably share the purchases, and then use for M&A is the anticipation if you will.

LEMKAU: Yes.

MCCRACKEN: OK. Will biotech and technology companies have a lot of cash as you were --

LEMKAU: Yes. It's really the big pharma companies with the big pharma companies as they look to grow, they probably going to deploy against biotech where the real fuel and the ability to drag the top line.

MCCRACKEN: Do you expect other certain trends that emerge in a given year? You know, when -- in 2016, you look back in a couple of years, you say that was the year of X or in 2008-2009, that was a certain, you know, era. What would you expect the trends might be in 2017?

LEMKAU: Yes. I think the big wave in 2017 partly fueled some of these cash repatriations, is going to be a significant amount of transaction across technology, media and telecom. You've seen the conversion happen in that sector, it was pretty remarkable. You've seen big transaction where Comcast bought NBC, Time Warner and AT&T trying to come together, even Verizon and Yahoo to an extent.

But the big distribution companies, looking to buy content, and the desire for this big media companies and big technology companies to get access to content and to get closer, to get some risk critical. And if you look -- you look at the Golden Globe last night, you had 17 nominations for shows or movies that was produced by Netflix or Amazon. I mean, imagine uttering that sentence five years ago.

And so, these companies acknowledging media and telecom, all of these are in content, all of these are in to get closer to consumer. I think needing to do that a lot via M&A.

MCCRACKEN: What's interesting is Amazon and Google, and even Apple have lots of cash. You know, everyday they're building our money, but they haven't done a lot of big deals. Do you expect that changes at some point? That they acquire, you know, acquire the arrivals or acquire entertainment companies.

LEMKAU: You see, that's the great question. I think these companies, you know, the five biggest market cap companies in the world are all with these big tech companies. They all happen to have big cash balances, sitting offshore, able to be brought back. And they've been really under penetrated in M&A.

So the real question is, when they will go pursue that as their top line growth starts to slow, which started. It's a natural time to do it. As the industry starts to converge is a natural time to do it. And the real question that really comes down to this regulatory piece, will the regulators allows them to do that, not just from the anti-trust standpoint but over our regulation where there's the FCC or the E.C. or the DOJ, of the FTC, will allow these big companies to get bigger via M&A.

MCCRACKEN: Is it the Goldman expectation, your expectation that the Trump administration be more like the Bush administration when it comes to anti- trust?

LEMKAU: I think it will be. You know, it's interesting a lot will remain to be seen. I think the hope is that we'll be a little bit looser. I'd say the Obama administration in the past year in particular, that a lot more stringent around M&A. There were $500 billion of transactions last year that fell way, largely due to anti-trust or interpretation of tax law. But if you look at Pfizer now or Baker Hughes and Halliburton, stay up for people (ph).

A lot of big deals fell away and the Obama administration kind of heading into their last year, got a lot more aggressive. I think the views that eases up to a degree and whether it returns all the way to that -- was under the Bush administration, that will get to be seen.

MCCRACKEN: Did you see situations where companies considered doing a deal. But, you know what, that will probably get a block here in this administration, let's read for that in a year.

LEMKAU: I think people that a lot of more anxious really as we head into 2016, and you saw some of these deals fall away. The last thing a board or a CEO wants to do is announce a big strategic transaction and how they can held up by the regulators for a long period of time. And then, ultimately, not happen.

It paralyzes a company. It's not great for the board. It's not great for the target or the buyer. And if somebody's transaction, we're getting stop, people really back to it in the table. I think if they see a looser regulatory environment, that much, more likely get back to the table.

MCCRACKEN: So Trump is going to have, he is in that real situation where he's going to have the House and the Senate, you know, but his party if you will. So as there, we're going to see big tax moves not just on repatriation but overall a big tax cut that might impact corporate taxes. How do you think that impacts M&A overall? What's that going to do to a company that's looking to do a deal?

LEMKAU: Yeah. I'd say, corporate tax cuts should also be a fuel to M&A. I think you'll see companies that have none core assets. It will be a lot easier to sell them if there's a reduce tax rate, and then having to have tax so we could just selling an asset. You'll see probably more divestitures than spin offs. I think people have been trying to do thing via tax, been off recently.

The one caveat to all of that is you may see a bit of a pause for awhile until it becomes clear what the tax rate is going to be. So you're going to sell an asset and you don't know if it's going to earn after tax at 35 percent or 25 percent or 15 percent. You probably want to wait to see what that new tax laws going to be but there's meaningful value, apparition around the actual earnings power of what you're selling.

So you could actually see a bit of a log until there's clarity around the tax report, and then a significant pick up and activity.

MCCRACKEN: All right. We're going to ask more questions for you. We throw that first back to Vonnie.

(BREAK)

MCCRACKEN: Thanks again, Vonnie.

So as Vonnie said, oil and gas could be busy this year. It was pretty slow in 2015-2016, maybe because a barrel of oil went from 100 something a barrel to as low as like $25 a barrel, I'm sure that had a big impact. What's your view or what oil and gas is going to do in 2017?

LEMKAU: Well, I mean, look at where the big energy companies, the oil and gas companies in particular, spent their time in focus in the past two years. It was really fixing their balance sheets and fixing their cost structures for dramatically reduce oil price. I had to figure out how to survive.

Lots of that self help is behind him, and you've got recovering oil price and you've got this general sense of optimism in the market that is likely to have all of them a lot more proactive around strategic activities. So I think you'll see a meaningful pick up in activity in the oil and gas piece, especially relative to what we saw in 2015 and 2016.

MCCRACKEN: What kind of impact does it have for a company when, you know, your core commodity, if the price of that is dropping so dramatically, you know, as I said, went from 100 I think in 2014 to below 30 in 2016. I mean, that just can't help a company who is thinking of putting himself on a block or considering expending billions to buy somebody.

LEMKAU: Well, it's fascinating. I think the companies that are in survival mode, need to really fix that capital structure. And most of them were built with CapEx budgets that didn't support $50 or that was more like $100 oil, so had a dramatically reshape that. I think the biggest companies who were positioned for the sustained downturn, weren't like they go and fix something off in the bottom because they want to make sure it was going to survive. They might rather see it go through bankruptcy and pick up the pieces.

I think a lot of the companies have now gotten through that, but the bottom has been hit and we start to recover and I think the biggest companies will feel a lot better about consolidating. And I think the smaller companies will fell like they not getting to a point where they can realize the value of doing an M&A transaction.

MCCRACKEN: It makes sense. It makes sense.

I want to circle back on something we're talking about earlier, which is M&A trust environment.

LEMKAU: Yes.

MCCRACKEN: And how -- there's a lot of things that would make a banker or a lawyer feel optimistic. What are some of the things that could be a concern in the M&A trust world? Because obviously, Donald Trump has been really fixated on jobs and maybe that starts to play into and could dampen some M&A this year.

LEMKAU: Yeah, I think that's right. I think a lot in the world is going to wait and see because you have a sense for how the new administration might behave in a pro business way but not exactly how they going to behave on any specific transaction or on transactions probably define. Lots of this consolidating transactions over the past year, who have been focus within the cost, which largely means taking that jobs. I think that's not going to be a sound bite or not going to be a narrative, this going to be particularly appealing in this administration.

I think the company is going to focus on doing big M&A transactions in particular, and the U.S. should be focus on, you know, creating a U.S. champion, or creating a winner in the U.S., of a global industry. And then, they go about doing an M&A transaction to create and focusing on growth and not focusing on cost cutting.

MCCRACKEN: Are there particular industries where jobs are more likely to be part of the equation in a big deal like industrial companies or oil and gas even?

LEMKAU: Yeah. I think the big consolidating transactions that have largely work have been industrial consolidation. We've actually seen it in consumer consolidation, the ability for these companies to come together and take out cost. Whether it's in a form of jobs, of sales people or R&D, have actually quite effective in driving the bottom line.

Again, but not necessarily feeding into the sentiment of where the countries going right now, which is going to be by creating jobs, is how I think they need reposition themselves around trying to put companies together in accelerated top line as opposed to just take out cost.

MCCRACKEN: I got it. Thanks, Gregg, good to have you.

LEMKAU: Thanks, Jeff.

MCCRACKEN: Back to you, Vonnie.

[*] ***END OF TRANSCRIPT***

urn:contentItem:5MKX-91S1-JBHT-D4WN-00000-00Goldman Sachs' Gregg Lemkau is Intvd on Blmbg TV2017-01-09T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:54:41ZLexisNexisGoldman Sachs' Gregg Lemkau is Intvd on Blmbg TVLanhamFULL TEXT

(This is not a legal transcript. Bloomberg LP cannot guarantee its accuracy.)

GREGG LEMKAU, GLOBAL HEAD OF M&A, GOLDMAN SACHS, ON BLOOMBERG TV

JANUARY 9, 2017

SPEAKERS: GREGG LEMKAU, GLOBAL HEAD OF M&A, GOLDMAN SACHS

JEFFREY MCCRACKEN, EXECUTIVE EDITOR FOR GLOBAL WHEEL, BLOOMBERG

[*] MCCRACKEN: Thank you, Bonnie. Yeah, you're right, it's quite a list. Welcome, Gregg.

LEMKAU: Thank you.

MCCRACKEN: So, 2016 was a good year, not quite up to the standards of say 2015. We had obviously big global deals, buyer in Monsanto, A.T., Time Warner, et cetera. What do you looking at 2017? What is your crystal ball say?

LEMKAU: Well, I think the outlook for M&A in 2017 is quite strong. A lot of the factors that existed in 2015 and '16 that drive activity continue to persist. So you have low interest rates. You got abundantly available capital. You've got limited growth opportunities for corporate organically. And you have positive equity markets.

So that's all still in place. I think more importantly, some of the headwinds we saw in 2016, it's slowdown activity, are started this upside. And I think specifically, the regulatory environment. I think the expectation is we'll have a little bit of an easier regulatory ..

(BREAK)

MCCRACKEN: Thanks again, Vonnie. I appreciate it. Sorry about that, Gregg.

LEMKAU: Sure.

MCCRACKEN: And I want to talk, so we wanted to give him an opportunity.

LEMKAU: Good idea.

MCCRACKEN: As you were saying, you expect easier regulatory environment in 2017.

LEMKAU: Yes. I think the expectation 2017 will be a bit of a loose for regulatory environment. And when you combine that with what we expect to be corporate tax reform, and in particular cash repatriation. It's actually a general sense of optimism in the business community, in particular, in corporate America that seems to be driving the desire to go out and be much more proactive on the strategic front.

MCCRACKEN: So how does repatriation? Is that something that's talk a lot about by, a lot by the M&A bankers in the M&A words? How do you think that might impact M&A? Because so many deals we've seen, you know, J&J right now talking to Kellyanne, a lot of these companies with offshore cast have used that to do deals in Europe, what happens if they bring that cash back to United States?

LEMKAU: So there something between $1 trillion to $2 trillion of cash trapped offshore by U.S. companies, and now the expectation will be able to bring that back in a relatively low tax rate and deployed in the U.S., so under deployed in a form of capital expenditures or in the form of M&A.

You've seen companies do lots of acquisitions outside the U.S. using that cash, but there a lot more targets in the U.S. and I think companies with the ability to deploy that capital in the U.S. whether it's a trillion or $2 trillion, and the cash that continue to generate back in the U.S., you'll see a big pick up in activity domestically.

MCCRACKEN: Yeah. And what are the industries that have the most offshore cash, is it tech for the most product?

LEMKAU: It's really the biggest the company. So it's mostly tech in big pharma but it's Google, Apple, Microsoft, Pfizer, J&J. You saw a lot of companies in the pharmaceutical industry, trying to do things to be able to access that cash offshore via M&A. If they can just bring that back and use it and deploy it via M&A in the U.S. they'll be able to do that much more easily.

MCCRACKEN: So they can bring it back, they'll use it for dividens. They'll use it for probably share the purchases, and then use for M&A is the anticipation if you will.

LEMKAU: Yes.

MCCRACKEN: OK. Will biotech and technology companies have a lot of cash as you were --

LEMKAU: Yes. It's really the big pharma companies with the big pharma companies as they look to grow, they probably going to deploy against biotech where the real fuel and the ability to drag the top line.

MCCRACKEN: Do you expect other certain trends that emerge in a given year? You know, when -- in 2016, you look back in a couple of years, you say that was the year of X or in 2008-2009, that was a certain, you know, era. What would you expect the trends might be in 2017?

LEMKAU: Yes. I think the big wave in 2017 partly fueled some of these cash repatriations, is going to be a significant amount of transaction across technology, media and telecom. You've seen the conversion happen in that sector, it was pretty remarkable. You've seen big transaction where Comcast bought NBC, Time Warner and AT&T trying to come together, even Verizon and Yahoo to an extent.

But the big distribution companies, looking to buy content, and the desire for this big media companies and big technology companies to get access to content and to get closer, to get some risk critical. And if you look -- you look at the Golden Globe last night, you had 17 nominations for shows or movies that was produced by Netflix or Amazon. I mean, imagine uttering that sentence five years ago.

And so, these companies acknowledging media and telecom, all of these are in content, all of these are in to get closer to consumer. I think needing to do that a lot via M&A.

MCCRACKEN: What's interesting is Amazon and Google, and even Apple have lots of cash. You know, everyday they're building our money, but they haven't done a lot of big deals. Do you expect that changes at some point? That they acquire, you know, acquire the arrivals or acquire entertainment companies.

LEMKAU: You see, that's the great question. I think these companies, you know, the five biggest market cap companies in the world are all with these big tech companies. They all happen to have big cash balances, sitting offshore, able to be brought back. And they've been really under penetrated in M&A.

So the real question is, when they will go pursue that as their top line growth starts to slow, which started. It's a natural time to do it. As the industry starts to converge is a natural time to do it. And the real question that really comes down to this regulatory piece, will the regulators allows them to do that, not just from the anti-trust standpoint but over our regulation where there's the FCC or the E.C. or the DOJ, of the FTC, will allow these big companies to get bigger via M&A.

MCCRACKEN: Is it the Goldman expectation, your expectation that the Trump administration be more like the Bush administration when it comes to anti- trust?

LEMKAU: I think it will be. You know, it's interesting a lot will remain to be seen. I think the hope is that we'll be a little bit looser. I'd say the Obama administration in the past year in particular, that a lot more stringent around M&A. There were $500 billion of transactions last year that fell way, largely due to anti-trust or interpretation of tax law. But if you look at Pfizer now or Baker Hughes and Halliburton, stay up for people (ph).

A lot of big deals fell away and the Obama administration kind of heading into their last year, got a lot more aggressive. I think the views that eases up to a degree and whether it returns all the way to that -- was under the Bush administration, that will get to be seen.

MCCRACKEN: Did you see situations where companies considered doing a deal. But, you know what, that will probably get a block here in this administration, let's read for that in a year.

LEMKAU: I think people that a lot of more anxious really as we head into 2016, and you saw some of these deals fall away. The last thing a board or a CEO wants to do is announce a big strategic transaction and how they can held up by the regulators for a long period of time. And then, ultimately, not happen.

It paralyzes a company. It's not great for the board. It's not great for the target or the buyer. And if somebody's transaction, we're getting stop, people really back to it in the table. I think if they see a looser regulatory environment, that much, more likely get back to the table.

MCCRACKEN: So Trump is going to have, he is in that real situation where he's going to have the House and the Senate, you know, but his party if you will. So as there, we're going to see big tax moves not just on repatriation but overall a big tax cut that might impact corporate taxes. How do you think that impacts M&A overall? What's that going to do to a company that's looking to do a deal?

LEMKAU: Yeah. I'd say, corporate tax cuts should also be a fuel to M&A. I think you'll see companies that have none core assets. It will be a lot easier to sell them if there's a reduce tax rate, and then having to have tax so we could just selling an asset. You'll see probably more divestitures than spin offs. I think people have been trying to do thing via tax, been off recently.

The one caveat to all of that is you may see a bit of a pause for awhile until it becomes clear what the tax rate is going to be. So you're going to sell an asset and you don't know if it's going to earn after tax at 35 percent or 25 percent or 15 percent. You probably want to wait to see what that new tax laws going to be but there's meaningful value, apparition around the actual earnings power of what you're selling.

So you could actually see a bit of a log until there's clarity around the tax report, and then a significant pick up and activity.

MCCRACKEN: All right. We're going to ask more questions for you. We throw that first back to Vonnie.

(BREAK)

MCCRACKEN: Thanks again, Vonnie.

So as Vonnie said, oil and gas could be busy this year. It was pretty slow in 2015-2016, maybe because a barrel of oil went from 100 something a barrel to as low as like $25 a barrel, I'm sure that had a big impact. What's your view or what oil and gas is going to do in 2017?

LEMKAU: Well, I mean, look at where the big energy companies, the oil and gas companies in particular, spent their time in focus in the past two years. It was really fixing their balance sheets and fixing their cost structures for dramatically reduce oil price. I had to figure out how to survive.

Lots of that self help is behind him, and you've got recovering oil price and you've got this general sense of optimism in the market that is likely to have all of them a lot more proactive around strategic activities. So I think you'll see a meaningful pick up in activity in the oil and gas piece, especially relative to what we saw in 2015 and 2016.

MCCRACKEN: What kind of impact does it have for a company when, you know, your core commodity, if the price of that is dropping so dramatically, you know, as I said, went from 100 I think in 2014 to below 30 in 2016. I mean, that just can't help a company who is thinking of putting himself on a block or considering expending billions to buy somebody.

LEMKAU: Well, it's fascinating. I think the companies that are in survival mode, need to really fix that capital structure. And most of them were built with CapEx budgets that didn't support $50 or that was more like $100 oil, so had a dramatically reshape that. I think the biggest companies who were positioned for the sustained downturn, weren't like they go and fix something off in the bottom because they want to make sure it was going to survive. They might rather see it go through bankruptcy and pick up the pieces.

I think a lot of the companies have now gotten through that, but the bottom has been hit and we start to recover and I think the biggest companies will feel a lot better about consolidating. And I think the smaller companies will fell like they not getting to a point where they can realize the value of doing an M&A transaction.

MCCRACKEN: It makes sense. It makes sense.

I want to circle back on something we're talking about earlier, which is M&A trust environment.

LEMKAU: Yes.

MCCRACKEN: And how -- there's a lot of things that would make a banker or a lawyer feel optimistic. What are some of the things that could be a concern in the M&A trust world? Because obviously, Donald Trump has been really fixated on jobs and maybe that starts to play into and could dampen some M&A this year.

LEMKAU: Yeah, I think that's right. I think a lot in the world is going to wait and see because you have a sense for how the new administration might behave in a pro business way but not exactly how they going to behave on any specific transaction or on transactions probably define. Lots of this consolidating transactions over the past year, who have been focus within the cost, which largely means taking that jobs. I think that's not going to be a sound bite or not going to be a narrative, this going to be particularly appealing in this administration.

I think the company is going to focus on doing big M&A transactions in particular, and the U.S. should be focus on, you know, creating a U.S. champion, or creating a winner in the U.S., of a global industry. And then, they go about doing an M&A transaction to create and focusing on growth and not focusing on cost cutting.

MCCRACKEN: Are there particular industries where jobs are more likely to be part of the equation in a big deal like industrial companies or oil and gas even?

LEMKAU: Yeah. I think the big consolidating transactions that have largely work have been industrial consolidation. We've actually seen it in consumer consolidation, the ability for these companies to come together and take out cost. Whether it's in a form of jobs, of sales people or R&D, have actually quite effective in driving the bottom line.

Again, but not necessarily feeding into the sentiment of where the countries going right now, which is going to be by creating jobs, is how I think they need reposition themselves around trying to put companies together in accelerated top line as opposed to just take out cost.

MCCRACKEN: I got it. Thanks, Gregg, good to have you.

LEMKAU: Thanks, Jeff.

MCCRACKEN: Back to you, Vonnie.

MCCRACKEN: Yeah. And what are the industries that have the most offshore cash, is it tech for the most product?

LEMKAU: It's really the biggest the company. So it's mostly tech in big pharma but it's Google, Apple, Microsoft, Pfizer, J&J. You saw a lot of companies in the pharmaceutical industry, trying to do things to be able to access that cash offshore via M&A. MCCRACKEN: So they can bring it back, they'll use it for dividens. They'll use it for probably share the purchases, and then use for M&A is the anticipation if you will.

LEMKAU: Yes.

MCCRACKEN: OK. Will biotech and technology companies have a lot of cash as you were --

LEMKAU: Yes. It's really the big pharma companies with the big pharma companies as they look to grow, they probably going to deploy against biotech where the real fuel and the ability to drag the top line.

MCCRACKEN: Do you expect other certain trends that emerge in a given year? You know, when -- in 2016, you look back in a couple of years, you say that was the year of X or in 2008-2009, that was a certain, you know, era. What would you expect the trends might be in 2017?

LEMKAU: Yes. I think the big wave in 2017 partly fueled some of these cash repatriations, is going to be a significant amount of transaction across technology, media and telecom. You've seen the conversion happen in that sector, it was pretty remarkable. You've seen big transaction where Comcast bought NBC, Time Warner and AT&T trying to come together, even Verizon and Yahoo to an extent.

But the big distribution companies, looking to buy content, and the desire for this big media companies and big technology companies to get access to content and to get closer, to get some risk critical. And if you look -- you look at the Golden Globe last night, you had 17 nominations for shows or movies that was produced by Netflix or Amazon. I mean, imagine uttering that sentence five years ago.

MCCRACKEN: What's interesting is Amazon and Google, and even Apple have lots of cash. You know, everyday they're building our money, but they haven't done a lot of big deals. Again, but not necessarily feeding into the sentiment of where the countries going right now, which is going to be by creating jobs, is how I think they need reposition themselves around trying to put companies together in accelerated top line as opposed to just take out cost.

JANUARY 9, 2017

JEFFREY MCCRACKEN, EXECUTIVE EDITOR FOR GLOBAL WHEEL, BLOOMBERG

[*] MCCRACKEN: Thank you, Bonnie. Yeah, you're right, it's quite a list. Welcome, Gregg.

LEMKAU: Thank you.

MCCRACKEN: So, 2016 was a good year, not quite up to the standards of say 2015. We had obviously big global deals, buyer in Monsanto, A.T., Time Warner, et cetera. What do you looking at 2017? What is your crystal ball say?

LEMKAU: Well, I think the outlook for M&A in 2017 is quite strong. A lot of the factors that existed in 2015 and '16 that drive activity continue to persist. So you have low interest rates. (BREAK)

LEMKAU: Sure.

MCCRACKEN: And I want to talk, so we wanted to give him an opportunity.

LEMKAU: Good idea.

MCCRACKEN: As you were saying, you expect easier regulatory environment in 2017.

LEMKAU: Yes. I think the expectation 2017 will be a bit of a loose for regulatory environment. And when you combine that with what we expect to be corporate tax reform, and in particular cash repatriation. It's actually a general sense of optimism in the business community, in particular, in corporate America that seems to be driving the desire to go out and be much more proactive on the strategic front.

You've seen companies do lots of acquisitions outside the U.S. using that cash, but there a lot more targets in the U.S. and I think companies with the ability to deploy that capital in the U.S. whether it's a trillion or $2 trillion, and the cash that continue to generate back in the U.S., you'll see a big pick up in activity domestically.

MCCRACKEN: Yeah. And what are the industries that have the most offshore cash, is it tech for the most product?

LEMKAU: It's really the biggest the company. So it's mostly tech in big pharma but it's Google, Apple, Microsoft, Pfizer, J&J. You saw a lot of companies in the pharmaceutical industry, trying to do things to be able to access that cash offshore via M&A. If they can just bring that back and use it and deploy it via M&A in the U.S. they'll be able to do that much more easily.

MCCRACKEN: So they can bring it back, they'll use it for dividens. They'll use it for probably share the purchases, and then use for M&A is the anticipation if you will.

LEMKAU: Yes.

MCCRACKEN: OK. Will biotech and technology companies have a lot of cash as you were --

LEMKAU: Yes. It's really the big pharma companies with the big pharma companies as they look to grow, they probably going to deploy against biotech where the real fuel and the ability to drag the top line.

MCCRACKEN: Do you expect other certain trends that emerge in a given year? You know, when -- in 2016, you look back in a couple of years, you say that was the year of X or in 2008-2009, that was a certain, you know, era. What would you expect the trends might be in 2017?

And if you look -- you look at the Golden Globe last night, you had 17 nominations for shows or movies that was produced by Netflix or Amazon. I mean, imagine uttering that sentence five years ago.

And so, these companies acknowledging media and telecom, all of these are in content, all of these are in to get closer to consumer. I think needing to do that a lot via M&A.

Do you expect that changes at some point? That they acquire, you know, acquire the arrivals or acquire entertainment companies.

LEMKAU: You see, that's the great question. I think these companies, you know, the five biggest market cap companies in the world are all with these big tech companies. They all happen to have big cash balances, sitting offshore, able to be brought back. And they've been really under penetrated in M&A.

So the real question is, when they will go pursue that as their top line growth starts to slow, which started. It's a natural time to do it. As the industry starts to converge is a natural time to do it. And the real question that really comes down to this regulatory piece, will the regulators allows them to do that, not just from the anti-trust standpoint but over our regulation where there's the FCC or the E.C. or the DOJ, of the FTC, will allow these big companies to get bigger via M&A.

MCCRACKEN: Is it the Goldman expectation, your expectation that the Trump administration be more like the Bush administration when it comes to anti- trust?

LEMKAU: I think it will be. You know, it's interesting a lot will remain to be seen. I think the hope is that we'll be a little bit looser. I'd say the Obama administration in the past year in particular, that a lot more stringent around M&A. There were $500 billion of transactions last year that fell way, largely due to anti-trust or interpretation of tax law. But if you look at Pfizer now or Baker Hughes and Halliburton, stay up for people (ph).

A lot of big deals fell away and the Obama administration kind of heading into their last year, got a lot more aggressive. I think the views that eases up to a degree and whether it returns all the way to that -- was under the Bush administration, that will get to be seen.

MCCRACKEN: Did you see situations where companies considered doing a deal. But, you know what, that will probably get a block here in this administration, let's read for that in a year.

LEMKAU: I think people that a lot of more anxious really as we head into 2016, and you saw some of these deals fall away. The last thing a board or a CEO wants to do is announce a big strategic transaction and how they can held up by the regulators for a long period of time. And then, ultimately, not happen.

It paralyzes a company. It's not great for the board. It's not great for the target or the buyer. And if somebody's transaction, we're getting stop, people really back to it in the table. I think if they see a looser regulatory environment, that much, more likely get back to the table.

MCCRACKEN: So Trump is going to have, he is in that real situation where he's going to have the House and the Senate, you know, but his party if you will. So as there, we're going to see big tax moves not just on repatriation but overall a big tax cut that might impact corporate taxes. How do you think that impacts M&A overall? What's that going to do to a company that's looking to do a deal?

It will be a lot easier to sell them if there's a reduce tax rate, and then having to have tax so we could just selling an asset. You'll see probably more divestitures than spin offs. I think people have been trying to do thing via tax, been off recently.

(BREAK)

MCCRACKEN: Thanks again, Vonnie.

So as Vonnie said, oil and gas could be busy this year. It was pretty slow in 2015-2016, maybe because a barrel of oil went from 100 something a barrel to as low as like $25 a barrel, I'm sure that had a big impact. What's your view or what oil and gas is going to do in 2017?

LEMKAU: Well, I mean, look at where the big energy companies, the oil and gas companies in particular, spent their time in focus in the past two years. It was really fixing their balance sheets and fixing their cost structures for dramatically reduce oil price. I had to figure out how to survive.

Lots of that self help is behind him, and you've got recovering oil price and you've got this general sense of optimism in the market that is likely to have all of them a lot more proactive around strategic activities. So I think you'll see a meaningful pick up in activity in the oil and gas piece, especially relative to what we saw in 2015 and 2016.

MCCRACKEN: What kind of impact does it have for a company when, you know, your core commodity, if the price of that is dropping so dramatically, you know, as I said, went from 100 I think in 2014 to below 30 in 2016. I mean, that just can't help a company who is thinking of putting himself on a block or considering expending billions to buy somebody.

LEMKAU: Well, it's fascinating. I think the companies that are in survival mode, need to really fix that capital structure. And most of them were built with CapEx budgets that didn't support $50 or that was more like $100 oil, so had a dramatically reshape that. I think the biggest companies who were positioned for the sustained downturn, weren't like they go and fix something off in the bottom because they want to make sure it was going to survive. And I think the smaller companies will fell like they not getting to a point where they can realize the value of doing an M&A transaction.

MCCRACKEN: It makes sense. It makes sense.

I want to circle back on something we're talking about earlier, which is M&A trust environment.

LEMKAU: Yes.

MCCRACKEN: And how -- there's a lot of things that would make a banker or a lawyer feel optimistic. What are some of the things that could be a concern in the M&A trust world? Because obviously, Donald Trump has been really fixated on jobs and maybe that starts to play into and could dampen some M&A this year.

LEMKAU: Yeah, I think that's right. I think a lot in the world is going to wait and see because you have a sense for how the new administration might behave in a pro business way but not exactly how they going to behave on any specific transaction or on transactions probably define. Lots of this consolidating transactions over the past year, who have been focus within the cost, which largely means taking that jobs. I think that's not going to be a sound bite or not going to be a narrative, this going to be particularly appealing in this administration.

I think the company is going to focus on doing big M&A transactions in particular, and the U.S. should be focus on, you know, creating a U.S. champion, or creating a winner in the U.S., of a global industry. And then, they go about doing an M&A transaction to create and focusing on growth and not focusing on cost cutting.

MCCRACKEN: Are there particular industries where jobs are more likely to be part of the equation in a big deal like industrial companies or oil and gas even?

LEMKAU: Yeah. I think the big consolidating transactions that have largely work have been industrial consolidation. Whether it's in a form of jobs, of sales people or R&D, have actually quite effective in driving the bottom line.

Again, but not necessarily feeding into the sentiment of where the countries going right now, which is going to be by creating jobs, is how I think they need reposition themselves around trying to put companies together in accelerated top line as opposed to just take out cost.

MCCRACKEN: I got it. Thanks, Gregg, good to have you.

LEMKAU: Thanks, Jeff.

Goldman Sachs is close to striking a deal with Amazon to offer small business loans to its US customers as the Wall Street bank turns to Big Tech to extend a push on to Main Street.

Goldman has begun building technology to facilitate the offering of loans to small and medium-sized businesses over Amazon’s lending platform, according to two people briefed on the discussions with the online retailer. The project could launch as soon as March, one of them said.

Goldman, which declined to comment, is in the midst of a transformation from a trading and investment banking powerhouse into a broader financial services group that more closely resembles rivals JPMorgan Chase and Citigroup. David Solomon, Goldman’s chief executive, last week told shareholders that the bank would boost returns by generating revenues from new sources such as consumer banking and wealth management.

For Amazon, a Goldman deal would be in line with Jeff Bezos’s push to turn the company into an infrastructure provider that profits from a growing chunk of online trade by charging for a host of commercial services offered to other companies.

John Cronin, an analyst at Goodbody’s, the brokerage, said banking partnerships could allow Amazon to “significantly extend” its small and medium-sized business lending platform “without any associated credit risk of regulatory obligations”.

Amazon declined to comment on the Goldman talks but said lending was one of the services provided to “our selling partners, mostly small and medium-sized businesses, who account for more than half of everything sold in Amazon’s stores”.

Amazon has already expanded far beyond its origins as an online bookseller by building businesses that sell petabytes of cloud computing space and state-of-the-art warehouse facilities to a variety of businesses.

It had outstanding small business loans of more than $863m on its own balance sheet at the end of 2019. For the past eight years it has lent to small businesses that sell on its site, using the data it holds on their cash positions to offer quick-decision loans in a handful of countries. 

An agreement with Amazon would follow last year’s credit card partnership between Goldman and Apple, which featured the bank’s branding on the physical card and in some marketing and gave Goldman a direct channel to Apple’s more than 100m US subscribers.

Executives at Goldman, which lacks the physical branch network that most banks use to attract small and medium-sized business customers, have described the Apple Card as the “most successful credit card launch ever”. Card lending is known to account for a significant portion of the $7bn of consumer loans and card balances the bank had at the end of last year. Goldman also offers consumer lending in the US through Marcus, its retail banking arm.

Goldman’s new consumer ventures accounted for less than 3 per cent of revenue last year, while the cards and consumer loan balances at the end of 2019 were less than 1 per cent of its $993bn in total assets. 

At its recent investor day it said it would pursue “banking-as-a-service” this year, which involves banks allowing third parties to “white label” their products.

urn:contentItem:5YX4-GHV1-JCMN-Y4V1-00000-00Goldman Sachs is going through a huge transformation under CEO David Solomon2020-05-15T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:54:41ZLexisNexisGoldman Sachs is going through a huge transformation under CEO David SolomonBusiness Insider

May 15, 2020( The Business Insider: http://www.businessinsider.com/ Delivered by Newstex) The storied investment bank is seeing leadership shakeups under CEO David Solomon and a slew of partner departures.Goldman has been moving away from high-risk businesses like trading and is making pushes into more stable areas like consumer lending,[1] wealth management, and transaction banking.There have been big cultural changes, too. Solomon is looking to create a more transparent workplace, while new tech execs are taking cues from Silicon Valley heavy-hitters.At Business Insider, we are closely tracking the latest developments at Goldman. You can read all of our Goldman coverage on BI Prime.[2] Storied Wall Street bank Goldman Sachs is going through some massive changes under CEO David Solomon.It's taken big steps involving transparency and inclusion to change up its culture. It has seen a slew of partner departures — many in the securities division.

And it's making big pushes into businesses like wealth management and transaction banking[3]. The latest on people moves, wealth strategyWhy Goldman Sachs, which has a $509 billion wealth business geared towards ultra-rich clients, is buying a small Virginia fintech for financial advisers and retail investors[4]Goldman Sachs just hired Kurt Hoffman, an expert in distressed situations and bankruptcy, to join a trading unit known for some of the bank's most lucrative deals[5]Goldman Sachs' top tech exec explains how a fresh slew of senior hires are transforming the bank's approach to building products[6]Read the full memo Goldman Sachs just sent naming 4 execs to lead its private-equity investments across the merchant-banking division[7]Culture and talentGoldman Sachs' summer internship is going virtual, joining the likes of Bank of America and Morgan Stanley who are running remote programs[8]Read the full memo Goldman Sachs just sent to staff announcing its new head of regulatory affairs. The former White House counsel will be tasked with helping clean up the bank's 1MDB drama.[9]Goldman Sachs just hired 2 senior recruiting execs focused on luring top talent from other firms —and it's a huge departure from the firm's traditional promote-from-within mentality[10]Read the full memo David Solomon just sent to 38,000 Goldman Sachs employees explaining why he's moving his management team out of stuffy offices and into open seating[11]Goldman Sachs CEO David Solomon and his management team are ditching their stuffy offices and moving to an open floor plan closer to the people so they can feel the buzz of New York headquarters[12]Goldman Sachs just unveiled a new gender pronouns initiative as part of a broader inclusion push at the Wall Street firm[13]Read the memo Goldman Sachs just sent to its employees unveiling a new pronouns initiative[14]Coronavirus responseInside a 38,000-person remote work rollout at Goldman Sachs: sleepless nights, assembly lines, and an Amazon-like hub on a Manhattan trading floor[15]How a massive New York hospital secured 130,000 N95 masks from China with help from a senior partner at Goldman Sachs, private jets, and a call to Warren Buffett[16]Goldman Sachs CEO David Solomon just sent a firm-wide voicemail about the coronavirus crisis. Here's what he told employees.[17]Goldman Sachs and Bank of America just updated their WFH policies — again. Here's what they're telling employees about the latest steps aimed at combating the spread of coronavirus.[18]Read the full memo Goldman Sachs top brass just sent detailing the firm's coronavirus contingency plans, including separating employees into 'blue' and 'white' teams to alternate working from the office and home[19]Consumer push, transaction banking, wealth managementGoldman Sachs just announced its first partnership for transaction banking as it looks to build a new $1 billion business moving money around the world[20]Goldman Sachs is sending much less mail to potential Marcus customers. A senior exec lays out the reason why.[21]A Goldman Sachs exec explains why the bank isn't sweating concerns over the Apple Card's profitability[22]A Wall Street firm crunched the numbers around how much Apple will make from its new credit card with Goldman Sachs[23]Here's why Goldman Sachs just did its biggest deal in nearly 20 years as part of a pivot to less wealthy clients[24]Goldman Sachs execs are opening up about their plans for Marcus, and they think it can do to banking what iTunes did to the music industry[25]Goldman Sachs' partnership with Apple could move it a step closer to being 'a bank branch in your pocket'[26]Human resources is the next battleground for Wall Street wealth advisers as Morgan Stanley and Goldman Sachs jockey over new turf[27]Goldman Sachs has a novel method for predicting the next economic slump, and it's at the heart of its hot new business[28]TechnologyJPMorgan and Goldman Sachs are finally beginning to embrace fintech startups. Here's how they test the waters before committing to working with them.[29]We talked to the execs behind Bloomberg's new data partnership with Goldman Sachs. Here's why they think it's a sign of Wall Street's future.[30]Goldman Sachs is putting its own Marquee app on Amazon's cloud in a pitch to lure more fintech developers[31]Goldman Sachs is embracing open-source code and its chief data officer says it's part of a "new world" of software[32]Read the memo the new Goldman tech chief sent to the firm's 9,000-plus engineers where he urges them to ditch presentations in favor of Amazon's famous narratives[33]A new Goldman Sachs tech exec hired from Amazon is taking a page from the Jeff Bezos playbook by urging engineers to ditch PowerPoint and write memos[34]Goldman Sachs' new CTO shares his strategy for attracting outside developers to work more closely with the bank, giving a glimpse into the future of how Wall Street will work[35]A Verizon executive is joining Goldman Sachs as chief technology officer as the Wall Street bank reshuffles its ranks[36]Marty Chavez is retiring from Goldman Sachs. We chatted with him about the bank's tech transformation, why now is the right time for him to step down, and what he's planning next.[37]Goldman Sachs tech guru Marty Chavez is retiring from the bank[38]Goldman Sachs' CEO just warned that the bank's big tech bets might not pay off as quickly as people hope[39]Goldman Sachs is scrapping a homegrown email app it once touted —and it's a sign the bank is moving away from building tech in house[40]Goldman Sachs is exploring plans to create a Netflix for data, and it marks a new frontier for Wall Street[41]Goldman Sachs' internal idea factory hatched a plan for the Google of Wall Street, and it's now looking for the next big thing to disrupt the bank[42]Goldman Sachs' big bet on the future of Wall Street had a rocky start. Here's the inside story of the bank's struggle to grow its next business and an exclusive look at its plans[43]TradingBank of America is shaking up its global markets division and poached a Goldman Sachs exec to fill a key new role[44]Goldman Sachs' massive quant business now rivals AQR and Two Sigma. We talked to the bank's top quant about asset growth, finding data sources, and why critics of computerized trading are wrong.[45]Goldman Sachs' CEO tells us the bank is winning over quant clients. That helped it outpace rivals like JPMorgan last quarter.[46]Goldman Sachs is cutting about 5% of sales and trading staff after senior equities leaders delivered a tough town-hall talk[47]Goldman Sachs is moving away from a tool championed by its former CFO as it pushes its traders to see clients where they once saw quick wins[48]Goldman Sachs is shuffling its top stock trading executives as the business tries to claw back market share from Morgan Stanley and JPMorgan[49]Goldman Sachs's bond trading unit is still trying to find its way — and it represents a key challenge for new CEO David Solomon[50]AlternativesRead the full memo Goldman Sachs just sent naming 4 execs to lead its private-equity investments across the merchant-banking division[51]Goldman Sachs is making targeted hires for a 'storefront' for alternative investments that's modeled after firms like KKR and Blackstone[52]Goldman Sachs' push into private equity is ruffling feathers at Blackstone — and it might be a sign of big client skirmishes to come[53]Goldman Sachs execs are jockeying for control of the firm's lucrative private investing units after a plan to merge it — and the stakes couldn't be higher[54]Meet the Goldman Sachs execs tasked with building the firms' new Blackstone-esque private-investing unit — and pumping up the bank's flagging stock price[55]'It's good to be Rich': Meet the Goldman Sachs banker who has built a private investing empire that goes head-to-head with Blackstone — and you've probably never heard of him[56]Goldman Sachs is considering a shakeup of its alternative investing units as part of a plan to simplify the bank's strategy[57]DealsGoldman Sachs is assembling a team of senior bankers focused on middle-market private equity. It shows how the bank is trying to reshape its strategy — and image.[66]Goldman Sachs just unveiled hundreds of slides laying out the future of the company. Here are the 10 crucial slides that show how it plans to transform into a bank for everyone.[67]Goldman Sachs is rethinking how it makes private-equity bets with its own money - and one analyst thinks that shift will be a big driver of its stock price[68]CareersGoldman Sachs is now hiring high-school graduates for roles in Salt Lake City, one of the company's 'high value' locations[69]Goldman Sachs has lost at least 54 partners since David Solomon became CEO.
